clues: This city is known as the City of Light
Home to the world's most visited museum
Famous for its iron tower
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was originally intended to be a temporary structure.
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the world's busiest pedestrian crossing.
Home to the oldest continuous imperial dynasty in the world.
fun_fact: This city has over 200 underground malls!
There's a building with a highway passing through its 5th, 6th, and 7th floors.
trivia: The city was formerly known as Edo until 1868.
This metropolis has more Michelin-starred restaurants than any other city.

clues: This city has a famous park in the center that spans over 840 acres.
Home to a large green statue that was a gift from France.
fun_fact: There's a hidden train platform underneath a famous hotel in this city.
Pizza delivery became popular in this city during a newspaper strike in 1945.
trivia: This city was briefly the capital of the United States in 1789.
The city's subway system has 472 stations, the most of any system worldwide.

clues: This ancient city was built on seven hills.
It's home to a famous circular amphitheater where gladiatorial contests were held.
fun_fact: This city has over 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
People have thrown approximately $1.5 million into one of its famous fountains annually.
trivia: The ancient Romans built a road network of over 250,000 miles radiating from this city.
This city contains the smallest country in the world within its boundaries.

clues: This city is known for its iconic opera house with sail-shaped roofs.
It hosted the Summer Olympics in 2000.
fun_fact: The famous harbor bridge in this city is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its shape.
This city's beaches have special nets to protect swimmers from sharks.
trivia: The opera house in this city has over one million roof tiles.
This was the first major city to see the new year due to its time zone location.

clues: This city is adjacent to some of the world's most famous ancient pyramids.
The longest river in the world runs through this capital city.
fun_fact: This city is known as 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its Islamic architecture.
The oldest university in the world that's still operating is located here, founded in 970 CE.
trivia: The city's traffic is so notorious that locals joke it's faster to walk than drive.
In ancient times, this area was known as Memphis and served as the capital of Ancient Egypt.

clues: This city is famous for a giant statue of Christ with outstretched arms.
It's known for hosting the world's largest carnival celebration.
fun_fact: The famous beach in this city has a sidewalk with a distinctive black and white wave pattern.
This city was once the capital of a European empire—the only time a European capital existed outside of Europe.
trivia: The iconic statue overlooking this city weighs 635 tons and stands 98 feet tall.
This was the first South American city to host the Summer Olympics.

clues: This city straddles two continents.
It was once known as Constantinople and Byzantium.
fun_fact: This city is home to the world's oldest covered market, the Grand Bazaar, with over 4,000 shops.
The city has been the capital of three different empires throughout history.
trivia: There are approximately 3,000 mosques throughout this city.
The Bosphorus Strait running through this city connects the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara.

clues: This city is famous for its iconic clock tower often incorrectly called by the name of its bell.
The monarch of the country resides in a palace in this city.
fun_fact: The subway system in this city is the oldest in the world, opening in 1863.
Despite its reputation for rain, this city actually receives less annual rainfall than Rome, Barcelona, or Sydney.
trivia: There are over 170 museums in this city, including one dedicated to fans and another to dental history.
The clock tower at the Houses of Parliament leans slightly at an angle of 0.04 degrees.

clues: This city contains a vast imperial palace complex known as the Forbidden City.
It hosted the Summer Olympics in 2008 and will host the Winter Olympics in 2022.
fun_fact: The Forbidden City has 9,999 rooms—purposely one room short of 10,000, which was thought to be the number of rooms in heaven.
Many taxi drivers in this city keep a cage of crickets in their cars for good luck.
trivia: The city was the capital of six ancient dynasties.
A famous wall stretching over 13,000 miles begins near this city.

clues: Home to the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest building.
Known for its luxury shopping and modern architecture.
A major business hub in the Middle East.
fun_fact: Dubai has man-made islands shaped like palm trees and a world map.
The Dubai Mall is one of the largest shopping malls in the world.
trivia: Dubai's police force uses supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.
Gold ATMs are common in Dubai.

clues: Home to Table Mountain.
Known for its beautiful coastal scenery and vineyards.
The legislative capital of South Africa.
fun_fact: Table Mountain is one of the oldest mountains in the world.
Cape Town is known as the 'Mother City' of South Africa.
trivia: Cape Town's Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden is one of the world's greatest botanical gardens.
The Cape of Good Hope is often mistaken as the southern tip of Africa, but it's actually Cape Agulhas.

clues: Known for the architectural works of Antoni Gaudí.
Home to the Sagrada Família and Park Güell.
Famous for its vibrant street life and beaches.
fun_fact: Barcelona's La Rambla is a famous pedestrian street filled with shops and performers.
The city has a unique urban layout called 'superblocks' to reduce traffic.
trivia: Barcelona's Boqueria Market is one of Europe's largest and most famous food markets.
The city's official languages are Catalan and Spanish.

clues: Built on 118 small islands
Known for gondola rides and canals
Hosts the Venice Film Festival
fun_fact: Venice’s buildings stand on wooden piles driven into the mud.
The city has no roads—only waterways and footpaths.
trivia: The Venetian mask tradition dates back to the 13th century.
Venice is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the World
Famous for Mughal-era architecture
Located on the banks of the Yamuna River
fun_fact: The Taj Mahal changes color depending on the time of day—pinkish at sunrise, milky white at noon, and golden under moonlight.
Agra Fort, a UNESCO site, once housed the legendary Peacock Throne before it was looted.
trivia: The Taj Mahal took 20,000 workers and 22 years to complete.
Agra was the capital of the Mughal Empire before Shah Jahan moved it to Delhi.
